BB10D877FD3347CABC111BF522C7CB84.description: Selects layout and highlights relevant structures and features to enhance the presentation

6D82FE5701D24D488D51843D0FDE406D.description: Adds descriptive words and sufficient details

11AA609232714666A4B632F174E86E46.description: Revision, i.e. making changes to content of text and/or message and/or meaning

5572657D5F1B4CEC820CDF2EEF5EAD6A.description: Uses a structure that fits the type of writing (e.g. letter format, narrative)

31F5042415A643D4AF8A895D4111C6E1.description: Writes to a specific wider audience on self-selected and assigned topics, issues and concerns

58B3FFE1C68A46D7883E80F76E17AC87.description: Writes to a specific familiar audience of family, friends and teacher

962434CF6C3F4738BB7D8B91C28E23A4.description: Drafting, i.e. initial version(s) of texts

F6DEC13393CE469993934C9851081CBB.description: Selects topic and text type based on purpose and audience

1E0B10DB5F374325BB1F743DEF0BB006.description: Understands the purpose for the writing (e.g., to entertain, to inform, to communicate)

B72D07F39F024178A523F0D7F6B7FFE9.description: Understands that texts must be questioned, since they are constructed by people with specific purposes in mind: Determines the specific or target audience by selecting details from the text (e.g. a magazine ad all in pink is probably targeting girls)

9417BAB09E534B3FBF846FB70617F882.description: Understands that all spoken, written and media texts are constructed by people to appeal to a specific or target audience

CD028326FCB84CB29E2AF7AF21A53D7F.description: Uses evidence to distinguish between own thinking, values and beliefs and those presented in the text (e.g. figures out what values are important to a character)

4867B7E2FEA54AE4B5231DBE89182758.description: Integrates new information with what is already known to construct meaning

B20A72EAFE044C24B49FC614B1E78C8E.description: Uses details and evidence in the text to infer meaning(s)

FDB7DA0C9EB84991A90D3940E5524013.description: Constructs a personal response to the text (i.e. constructs meaning)

5106DB0103834C70A98BA9205560467C.description: Uses the purpose for reading and clues in the text to determine important aspects of a text (e.g. nonfiction features that signal importance such as boldface print, italics)

EBF989CAF6504EEE8963083495370903.description: Feedback: seeks and provides throughout all stages of the writing process

0291701AA26C4D51B6B176384796715E.description: Relies on common structures and features of media texts to construct meaning

9D29779189814657BF55E6A3A5797F51.description: Relies on common structures and features of literary, popular and information-based texts to construct meaning (e.g. narrative structure: beginning, middle, end; or a feature such as dialogue)

B0CFB52FED364BCBB5F0932FE41D4567.description: Applies knowledge of cueing systems to construct meaning

6656286B7B9E4EF198B1514ED9E186F2.description: Makes explicit connections between own personal experiences and story experiences

3F9F223C8BA54B7393D4DB612982AA2D.description: Builds needed background knowledge and experiences (e.g. of content, setting and/or author, in a variety of ways such as watching a documentary on a related topic, reading a picture book on a similar theme before reading a chapter book, using the Internet

D09BA702878E485181062DD584DD0B46.description: Uses knowledge of the genre/text type to be viewed/read: immersion into models of the text type to determine important structures and features of the text type, and how these contribute to meaning in the text (e.g. understands the structure and features o

45E04BB1033B4B8D8CDA64863C43DCDB.description: Previews the text (e.g. attends to the cover, dedication, title page and author’s notes for clues that will add to understanding or enjoyment of the text)

CD5B0ADABEFA428897A6624E2452EECB.description: Understands the purpose for reading, listening to and/or viewing (e.g. for enjoyment, to learn something, to escape to new places, for instructions)

5C92F90B9405486D93D94BEB5F0F05DD.description: Uses and interprets the visual element of color (e.g. dark reds and blacks in a picture book to show anger or fear)

6158D181BEFE48229CFDF1F3E97F2EE8.description: Punctuation: Applies end punctuation rules: period, question mark, exclamation point, Applies rules for commas: items in a series, greetings, Uses apostrophes to punctuate contractions and singular possessive, Uses quotation marks to punctuate dialogue.

A0C093D3655C44C4B72E54B578C878DB.description: Capitalization: Applies capitalization rules: the first word in a sentence, proper nouns

6D0F7BD3A00842C98F7287CFD9B863AE.description: Selects words that convey the intended meaning and create a picture in the reader’s mind

5C5B0CFCAEF24F01AEB19EB82AAD25BA.description: Uses consistent verb tenses and correct pronoun references

F7A5C3435EE04771811522CA59F52284.description: Uses vocabulary and/or terminology related to the type of writing
